content: why lock here welcome back non-player characters they're people too
and they need a livelihood so let's take a break from doing tiles for a moment
and do some scenery this is a potion vendor this method for texturing wood
and the paint scheme I'm about to walk through came from Kuro Finn on the DMS
craft forum I'll place a link to that thread on the screen now get about
thirty standard popsicle sticks using a wood chisel V gouge or anything with a
tough metal corner carve out erratic lines of varying lengths in order to
make a wooden plank texture do this on both sides of the popsicle stick all
painting will be done to both sides of the planks base completely in black next
apply a light coat of burnt umber really this is a second base coat but lightly
applied you basically want to cover the entire piece except for the cracks which
should remain black so draw the brush against the grain not along with it
next use an orangish brown such as terracotta shown here and apply a
healthy dry brush finally use a tan or khaki color such as honey Brown shown
here you will dry brush this color with the same intensity as the previous color
but only hit about half the plank in a chaotic manner if done right it will
almost look like stripes of the orange and tan colors here's a close-up of the
planks with painting complete you
take five planks and chop off the curved ends lay out a piece of tape any kind
will do and stick all five to it tightly next to each other
with the flat ends flush the tape serves as a temporary measure to keep the
planks in place for the next couple of steps measure the width of this assembly
it should be about one and seven eighths of an inch cut another plank to that
length and then hot glue it to secure these five together this cross beam
should be about a quarter inch from the bottom as shown here now on one side
measure up one and three quarters of an inch and Mark on the other side measure
up two and three quarters of an inch and Mark connect these two marks and cut
your cutting wood here so be patient just keep lightly scoring and after a
dozen or so passes you should be all the way through this is one side of the
shack now repeat the entire process to build the other side however when you
measure up the sides ensure that you are making a mirror image of the first wall
that you made next we'll make the back wall measure and cut seven pieces all at
one and three-quarters of an inch just as before stick them to tape measure the
width and cut a crossbeam and glue the crossbeam to bind all seven together
last let's make the front wall measure and cut seven pieces all at one inch in
length stick them to tape measure and cut a cross beam and glue the cross beam
to bind all seven together it's time to assemble the walls I have a
square scrap here which I'm using as a jig to ensure that the first two walls
are at a perfect 90 degree angle but this really isn't necessary hot glue
even when cooled is just flexible enough that you can eyeball this joint and
it'll be close enough next attach the other wall and after that the front now
measure the two directions to get the dimensions for the roof it should be
roughly two and a quarter inch by 2 and 7/8 of an inch get some single
corrugated cardboard and cut out this rectangle but be sure the corrugation is
oriented the right way peel off the paper from one side this looks pretty
good but is a little flimsy so get some chipboard cardstock or any sturdy scraps
and cut another rectangle of the same size glue it to the corrugated piece now
for those out there who have actual artistic talent unlike me you can paint
this metal roof however you like I will simply slather it with metallic gunmetal
gray set the roof aside take a plank and cut it to length to fit
on the back wall this will be a shelf there's room for two shelves so cut two
planks if you like now let's make some potions the two exact products I'm using
here both come from Michael's the body of the potion is from this rainbow glass
assorted bead collection and it comes in this half circle shaped container the
potion caps are these Toho seed beads this method came from DM Brad on the DMS
craft forum here's a link to that thread I recommend using needlenose pliers
and a small gage glue gun it's pretty simple pick a bead and glue a cap to it
lay out your potions on your shelves so you know they'll be spaced out properly
now this video is for a potion vendor but I'm going to take the opportunity to
stock these shelves with some other things as well such as books and a
dagger simply hot glue your shelves contents to the Shelf when done hot glue
the shelves onto the back wall the bottom shelf should be pretty close to
the floor maybe only an eighth of an inch up to ensure that there's enough
room for the upper shelf note you may wish to hold off construction of the
Shack until after you've done this step as I was assembling the video the
thought occurred to me that that would have been far easier
lastly glue on the roof and you're done okay and now for a little fly about the
flash on here I apologize the lighting quality is so poor in my videos but I'm
using my LG spectrum 2 smartphone for all this big-time stuff so here's the
finished product there's the shopkeep that's willow the half elf from our most
recent campaign here's a bigger version I actually built this first it's bigger
it's got a door for the miniature to be able to fit through if that's relevant
to you make this one was slightly taller also but for the video I decided to make
a smaller one variety is good so one more side-by-side shot here and I'm
pretty happy with how these turned out so in context here's the bazaar and in
town here's the jeweler he's got some crystals those are Swarovski and rings
and stuff and then we come over and here is the potion vendor so you can imagine
this being on a street or something and they're going about their business just
fine that is till of course that all of a sudden a bone Naga shows up and starts
to terrorize them but that's for another time so thank you for joining me my luck
I'll see you next time
